items.body:
# Daily Perf Improver - Phase 2: Build Configuration and Performance Engineering Guides

## Summary

This PR completes the Phase 2 setup for the Daily Perf Improver workflow by adding:

1. **Build Steps Configuration** - Automated environment setup for performance development
2. **Performance Engineering Guides** - Comprehensive documentation for rapid performance iteration

## Changes

### 1. Build Steps Action (`.github/actions/daily-perf-improver/build-steps/action.yml`)

Automated setup for performance development environment:
- Sets up Node.js, Bun, and Deno from `.tool-versions`
- Installs dependencies with frozen lockfile
- Builds the project
- Verifies build output
- Logs all steps to `build-steps.log` in repo root

**Usage in workflow:**
```yaml
- uses: ./.github/actions/daily-perf-improver/build-steps
```

### 2. Performance Engineering Guides (`.github/copilot/instructions/`)

Five comprehensive guides to enable rapid performance iteration:

#### `runtime-performance-optimization.md`
- HTTP and router benchmarking workflows
- Hot path optimization techniques (router, middleware, Context)
- Memory optimization strategies
- Runtime-specific tips (Cloudflare Workers, Deno, Bun, Node.js, Lambda)
- Measurement best practices and statistical rigor

#### `build-and-test-performance.md`
- Build time optimization (parallel builds, incremental type checking, caching)
- Test execution speed (parallelization, filtering, coverage optimization)
- CI performance optimization strategies
- Fast iteration loops for performance work
- Development workflow optimization

#### `bundle-size-optimization.md`
- Bundle size monitoring and analysis
- Tree-shaking optimization techniques
- Dependency reduction strategies
- Size budget enforcement
- Analysis tools (esbuild metafile, source-map-explorer)
- Common bundle size pitfalls

#### `performance-measurement-guide.md`
- Existing benchmark infrastructure overview (HTTP, router, JSX)
- Creating new benchmarks (templates, best practices)
- Statistical significance and avoiding false positives
- CI integration for automated performance checks
- Troubleshooting inconsistent results

#### `framework-performance-patterns.md`
- Core performance principles (zero-cost abstractions, pay-for-what-you-use)
- Common performance anti-patterns (excessive middleware, blocking ops, unnecessary parsing)
- Runtime-specific optimizations for all supported platforms
- Multi-runtime compatibility patterns
- Performance debugging techniques (profiling, flame graphs)
- API design checklist for performance

## How These Guides Enable Rapid Iteration

Each guide is structured for quick reference during performance work:

1. **Quick Start sections** - Get measuring immediately
2. **Focused workflows** - Step-by-step optimization processes
3. **Example code** - Copy-paste ready templates
4. **Measurement strategies** - Know what to measure and how
5. **Checklists** - Don't miss critical steps
6. **Troubleshooting** - Common issues and solutions

## Testing

The build-steps action is designed to run in GitHub Actions workflow context and cannot be fully tested in this environment without Bun/Deno installed. However:

- [x] Action syntax validated (YAML structure correct)
- [x] Steps mirror existing CI workflows (`.github/workflows/ci.yml`)
- [x] Uses same setup actions as CI (setup-node@v4, setup-bun@v2, setup-deno@v2)
- [x] Tool versions sourced from `.tool-versions` (consistent with CI)
- [x] Build command matches `package.json` scripts
- [x] Logging appends to `build-steps.log` as specified

## Next Steps

After this PR is merged:

1. **Phase 3** will automatically begin - The Daily Perf Improver will:
   - Use the build-steps action to set up environment
   - Reference these guides for optimization work
   - Select goals from the performance plan (Discussion #2)
   - Implement performance improvements
   - Create PRs with measured impact

2. **Maintainer review requested** for:
   - Accuracy of performance guidance
   - Appropriateness of optimization priorities
   - Any Hono-specific concerns not captured

## Related

- **Planning Discussion**: #2 (Daily Perf Improver - Research and Plan)
- **Workflow**: `.github/workflows/daily-perf-improver.md`

## Checklist

- [x] Build steps action created with proper structure
- [x] All 5 performance guides created
- [x] Guides cover all areas from research phase
- [x] Cross-referenced with existing CI configuration
- [x] Build commands validated against package.json
- [x] Tool versions sourced from .tool-versions
- [x] No temporary files included
- [x] Ready for Phase 3 implementation

---

**Note**: This PR intentionally does not include performance improvements yet. Phase 2 focuses on configuration and documentation to enable Phase 3 optimization work.

Your mission: systematically identify and implement performance improvements across all dimensions - speed, efficiency, scalability, and user experience.\n\nYou are doing your work in phases. Right now you will perform just one of the following three phases. Choose the phase depending on what has been done so far.\n\n## Phase selection\n\nTo decide which phase to perform:\n\n1. First check for existing open discussion titled \"Daily Perf Improver\" using `list_discussions`. If found, read it and maintainer comments. If not found, then perform Phase 1 and nothing else.\n\n2. Next check if `.github/actions/daily-perf-improver/build-steps/action.yml` exists. If yes then read it. If not then perform Phase 2 and nothing else.\n\n3. Finally, if both those exist, then perform Phase 3.\n\n## Phase 1 - Performance research\n\n1. Research performance landscape in this repo:\n  - Current performance testing practices and tooling\n  - User-facing performance concerns (load times, responsiveness, throughput)\n  - System performance bottlenecks (compute, memory, I/O, network)\n  - Maintainer performance priorities and success metrics\n  - Development/build performance issues affecting performance engineering\n  - Existing performance documentation and measurement approaches\n\n  **Identify optimization targets:**\n  - User experience bottlenecks (slow page loads, UI lag, high resource usage)\n  - System inefficiencies (algorithms, data structures, resource utilization)\n  - Development workflow pain points affecting performance engineering (build times, test execution, CI duration)\n  - Infrastructure concerns (scaling, deployment, monitoring)\n  - Performance engineering gaps (lack of guides, rapidity, measurement strategies)\n\n  **Goal:** Enable engineers to quickly measure performance impact across different dimensions using appropriate tools - from quick synthetic tests to realistic user scenarios.\n\n2. Use this research to create a discussion with title \"Daily Perf Improver - Research and Plan\"\n\n3. Exit this entire workflow, do not proceed to Phase 2 on this run. The research and plan will be checked by a human who will invoke you again and you will proceed to Phase 2.\n\n## Phase 2 - Build steps inference and configuration and perf engineering guides\n\n1. Check for open PR titled \"Daily Perf Improver - Updates to complete configuration\". If exists then comment \"configuration needs completion\" and exit.\n\n2. Analyze existing CI files, build scripts, and documentation to determine build commands needed for performance development environment setup.\n\n3. Create `.github/actions/daily-perf-improver/build-steps/action.yml` with validated build steps. Each step must log output to `build-steps.log` in repo root. Cross-check against existing CI/devcontainer configs.\n\n4. Create 1-5 performance engineering guides in `.github/copilot/instructions/` covering relevant areas (e.g., frontend performance, backend optimization, build performance, infrastructure scaling). Each guide should document:\n  - Performance measurement strategies and tooling\n  - Common bottlenecks and optimization techniques\n  - Success metrics and testing approaches\n  - How to do explore performance efficiently using focused, maximally-efficient measurements and rebuilds\n\n5. Create PR with title \"Daily Perf Improver - Updates to complete configuration\" containing files from steps 2d-2e. Request maintainer review. Exit workflow.\n\n6. Test build steps manually. If fixes needed then update the PR branch. If unable to resolve then create issue and exit.\n\n7. Exit this entire workflow, do not proceed to Phase 3 on this run. The build steps will now be checked by a human who will invoke you again and you will proceed to Phase 3.\n\n## Phase 3 - Goal selection, work and results\n\n1. **Goal selection**. Build an understanding of what to work on and select a part of the performance plan to pursue\n\n   a. Repository is now performance-ready. Review `build-steps/action.yml` and `build-steps.log` to understand setup. If build failed then create fix PR and exit.\n   \n   b. Read the plan in the discussion mentioned earlier, along with comments.\n\n   c. Check for existing performance PRs (especially yours with \"Daily Perf Improver\" prefix). Avoid duplicate work.\n   \n   d. If plan needs updating then comment on planning discussion with revised plan and rationale. Consider maintainer feedback.\n  \n   e. Select a performance improvement goal to pursue from the plan. Ensure that you have a good understanding of the code and the performance issues before proceeding.\n\n   f. Select and read the appropriate performance engineering guide(s) in `.github/copilot/instructions/` to help you with your work. If it doesn't exist, create it and later add it to your pull request.\n\n2. **Work towards your selected goal**. For the performance improvement goal you selected, do the following:\n\n   a. Create a new branch starting with \"perf/\".\n   \n   b. Work towards the performance improvement goal you selected. Consider approaches like:\n     - **Code optimization:** Algorithm improvements, data structure changes, caching\n     - **User experience:** Reducing load times, improving responsiveness, optimizing assets\n     - **System efficiency:** Resource utilization, concurrency, I/O optimization\n     - **Performance engineering workflow:** Build optimization, test performance, CI improvements for faster performance engineering\n     - **Infrastructure:** Scaling strategies, deployment efficiency, monitoring setup\n\n     **Measurement strategy:**\n     Plan before/after measurements using appropriate methods for your performance target - synthetic benchmarks for algorithms, user journey tests for UX, load tests for scalability, or build time comparisons for developer experience. Choose reliable measurement approaches that clearly demonstrate impact.\n\n   c. Ensure the code still works as expected and that any existing relevant tests pass. Add new tests if appropriate and make sure they pass too.\n\n   d. Measure performance impact. Document measurement attempts even if unsuccessful. If no improvement then iterate, revert, or try different approach.\n\n   e. Apply any automatic code formatting used in the repo\n\n   f. Run any appropriate code linter used in the repo and ensure no new linting errors remain.\n\n3. **Results and learnings**\n\n   a. If you succeeded in writing useful code changes that improve performance, create a draft pull request with your changes. \n\n      **Critical:** Exclude performance reports and tool-generated files from PR. Double-check added files and remove any that don't belong.\n\n      Include a description of the improvements with evidence of impact. Make any necessary corrections by pushing further commits to the branch.\n\n   b.   {
    "type": "function",
    "function": {
      "name": "str_replace_editor",
      "description": "Editing tool for viewing, creating and editing files\n     * State is persistent across command calls and discussions with the user\n     * If `path` is a file, `view` displays the result of applying `cat -n`. If `path` is a directory, `view` lists non-hidden files and directories up to 2 levels deep\n     * The `create` command cannot be used if the specified `path` already exists, or if parent directories don't exist\n     * If a `command` generates a long output, output will be truncated and marked with `<file too long...`\n     * Path *must* be absolute\n\n     Notes for using the `str_replace` command:\n     * The `old_str` parameter should match EXACTLY one or more consecutive lines from the original file\n     * If the `old_str` parameter is not unique in the file, replacement will not be performed. Make sure to include enough context in `old_str` to make it unique\n     * The `new_str` parameter should contain the edited lines that should replace the `old_str`",
      "parameters": {
        "type": "object",
        "properties": {
          "command": {
            "type": "string",
            "enum": [
              "view",
              "create",
              "str_replace",
              "insert"
            ],
            "description": "The commands to run. Allowed options are: `create`, `view`, `str_replace`, `insert`."
          },
          "file_text": {
            "description": "Required parameter of `create` command; the content of the file to be created.",
            "type": "string"
          },
          "insert_line": {
            "description": "Required parameter of `insert` command. The `new_str` will be inserted AFTER the line `insert_line` of `path`.",
            "type": "integer"
          },
          "new_str": {
            "description": "Required parameter of `str_replace` command containing the new string. Required parameter of `insert` command containing the string to insert.",
            "type": "string"
          },
          "old_str": {
            "description": "Required parameter of `str_replace` command containing the string in `path` to replace. Leading and ending whitespaces from file content should be preserved!",
            "type": "string"
          },
          "path": {
            "description": "Absolute path to file or directory.",
            "type": "string"
          },
          "view_range": {
            "description": "Optional parameter of `view` command when `path` points to a file. If none is given, the full file is shown. If provided, the file will be shown in the indicated line number range, e.g. [11, 12] will show lines 11 and 12. Indexing at 1 to start. Setting `[start_line, -1]` shows all lines from `start_line` to the end of the file.",
            "items": {
              "type": "integer"
            },
            "type": "array"
          }
        },
        "required": [
          "command",
          "path"
        ]
      }
    }
  },

This research identifies optimization opportunities across runtime performance, build/test efficiency, and developer experience.\n\n---\n\n## Current Performance Infrastructure\n\n### ✅ Existing Performance Tooling\n\n**HTTP Performance Benchmarking**\n- Automated HTTP benchmark using bombardier in CI (`benchmarks/http-server/`)\n- Compares main vs PR branches automatically\n- Posts results Optimizations**\n- **RegExpRouter** is the default, marketed as \"really fast\"\n- Multiple router implementations (Trie, Pattern, Linear, Smart)\n- Opportunity: Profile and optimize hot paths in router matching\n- Opportunity: Reduce allocations in route parameter extraction\n- Opportunity: Investigate SIMD or other low-level optimizations\n\n**Middleware Performance**\n- 20+ built-in middleware (JWT, CORS, compression, etc.)\n- Opportunity: Profile middleware overhead\n- Opportunity: Lazy-load middleware to reduce startup time\n- Opportunity: Optimize common middleware chains\n\n**Request/Response Handling**\n- Context object creation on every request\n- Opportunity: Object pooling for high-frequency allocations\n- Opportunity: Optimize header parsing and manipulation\n- Opportunity: Reduce closure allocations in hot paths\n\n**JSX Rendering**\n- Server-side JSX rendering with streaming support\n- Opportunity: Optimize JSX transformation and rendering pipeline\n- Opportunity: Improve streaming performance\n\n### ⚡ Category 2: Build & Development Performance\n\n**Build Time Optimization**\n- Custom build script using esbuild (`build/build.ts`)\n- Builds both ESM and CJS outputs with type definitions\n- Glob-based entry point discovery\n- Opportunity: Parallel build optimization\n- Opportunity: Incremental build support\n- Opportunity: Build cache strategies\n\n**Test Execution Speed**\n- Vitest with multiple projects (main, fastly, node, workerd, lambda)\n- Deno and Bun runtime tests\n- Coverage generation\n- Opportunity: Test parallelization optimization\n- Opportunity: Reduce test setup overhead\n- Opportunity: Selective test execution based on changes\n\n**Type Checking Performance**\n- Already measures type check time\n- Tests with 200-route applications\n- Opportunity: Optimize type definitions to reduce inference complexity\n- Opportunity: Split type checking for faster feedback\n\n**CI/CD Performance**\n- Comprehensive CI with 12+ jobs\n- Multiple runtime validations\n- Opportunity: Job parallelization review\n- Opportunity: Cached dependencies optimization\n- Opportunity: Selective job execution based on changes\n\n### 📦 Category 3: Bundle & Distribution\n\n**Bundle Size Optimization**\n- Already tracking with octocov\n- \"hono/tiny\" preset advertised as under 12kB\n- Tree-shaking support\n- Opportunity: Analyze and reduce core bundle size further\n- Opportunity: Identify and eliminate dead code\n- Opportunity: Optimize for common use cases\n\n**Code Splitting**\n- Multiple entry points (preset/tiny, preset/quick, adapters, middleware)\n- Opportunity: Ensure optimal chunking for common patterns\n- Opportunity: Reduce shared bundle overhead\n\n### 🔧 Category 4: Developer Experience Performance\n\n**Startup Time**\n- Import and initialization speed\n- Opportunity: Lazy initialization of optional features\n- Opportunity: Reduce eager evaluations\n\n**Hot Module Replacement**\n- Watch mode exists (`bun run watch`)\n- Opportunity: Optimize rebuild times during development\n- Opportunity: Improve dev server responsiveness\n\n**Documentation & Examples**\n- No dedicated performance guide for users\n- Opportunity: Create performance best practices guide\n- Opportunity: Document performance characteristics of routers/middleware\n- Opportunity: Provide optimization patterns and anti-patterns\n\n---\n\n## Proposed Performance Engineering Guides\n\nTo enable rapid performance iteration, create these guides in `.github/copilot/instructions/`:\n\n1. **`runtime-performance-optimization.md`**\n   - Router and middleware profiling techniques\n   - Memory allocation reduction strategies\n   - Request/response path optimization\n   - Benchmarking methodology for runtime changes\n\n2. **`build-and-test-performance.md`**\n   - Fast build iteration strategies\n   - Test execution optimization\n   - Type checking acceleration\n   - CI performance improvement techniques\n\n3. **`bundle-size-optimization.md`**\n   - Bundle analysis workflows\n   - Tree-shaking verification\n   - Import cost analysis\n   - Size regression prevention\n\n4. **`performance-measurement-guide.md`**\n   - How to use existing benchmark suite\n   - Creating new benchmarks\n   - Interpreting performance results\n   - Statistical significance and noise Target: 20-30% faster clean builds\n   - Rationale: Developer experience, CI time costs\n   - Measurement: Build time comparisons\n\n3. **Test Execution Speed**\n   - Target: 15-25% faster test runs\n   - Rationale: Faster feedback, cheaper CI\n   - Measurement: Test suite timing\n\n### 🥈 Medium Priority (Strategic Value)\n\n4. **Bundle Size Reduction**\n   - Target: Reduce core by 5-10%\n   - Measurement Strategy\n\n### Before/After Comparison Methodology\n\n**For Runtime Changes:**\n- Use existing HTTP benchmark suite (bombardier)\n- Run router benchmarks with mitata\n- Multiple runs (5-10) for statistical confidence\n- Report median and p95 latencies\n- Compare against main branch baseline\n\n**For Build Changes:**\n- Time clean builds (bun run build)\n- Time incremental rebuilds\n- Measure dist/ output size\n- Compare against baseline with warm/cold states\n\n**For Test Changes:**\n- Use vitest timing output\n- Measure per-project execution time\n- Track coverage generation time\n- Compare total CI duration\n\n**Statistical Rigor:**\n- Eliminate environmental noise\n- Use consistent hardware (CI runners)\n- Multiple iterations for confidence intervals\n- Document measurement limitations\n\n---\n\n## Risk Assessment\n\n### Low Risk\n- Documentation improvements\n- Adding new benchmarks\n- Build script optimizations (with rollback)\n\n### Medium Risk\n- Type definition changes (may affect user code)\n- Bundle configuration changes (may affect imports)\n- Test infrastructure changes (may mask issues)\n\n### High Risk\n- Router algorithm changes (core functionality)\n- API changes affecting middleware (breaking changes)\n- Build output format changes (ecosystem compatibility)\n\n**Mitigation:** All changes must pass existing test suite. Performance improvements should not compromise correctness or API stability.\n\n---\n\n## Next Steps\n\nOnce this plan is approved:\n\n1. Create performance engineering guides (Phase 2)\n2. Set up build automation for performance testing (Phase 2)\n3. Begin implementing optimizations according to priority (Phase 3+)\n4. Measure and document impact\n5. This guide covers architectural patterns, common performance pitfalls, runtime-specific optimizations, and best practices for multi-runtime support.\\n\\n## Core Performance Principles\\n\\n### 1. Zero-Cost Abstractions\\n\\nHono aims for abstractions that compile away or have negligible runtime cost:\\n\\n**Good:**\\n```typescript\\n// Middleware composition that doesn't add overhead\\napp.use(middleware1)\\napp.use(middleware2)\\n// Compiled into direct function calls, no extra layers\\n```\\n\\n**Avoid:**\\n```typescript\\n// Unnecessary wrapper layers\\napp.use((c, next) => {\\n  return someWrapper(() => {\\n    return someOtherWrapper(() => {\\n      return actualMiddleware(c, next)\\n    })\\n  })\\n})\\n```\\n\\n### 2. Pay-for-What-You-Use\\n\\nOnly include code that's actually needed:\\n\\n```typescript\\n// Core import - minimal\\nimport { Hono } from 'hono'\\n\\n// Middleware is opt-in\\nimport { jwt } from 'hono/jwt'\\nimport { cors } from 'hono/cors'\\n\\n// Tree-shaking eliminates unused middleware\\n```\\n\\n### 3. Hot Path Optimization\\n\\nOptimize code that runs on every request:\\n\\n**Hot paths in Hono:**\\n- Router matching\\n- Context object creation\\n- Middleware execution chain\\n- Response generation\\n\\n**Cold paths (less critical):**\\n- Application initialization\\n- Route registration\\n- Development-only utilities\\n\\nFocus optimization effort on hot paths.\\n\\n## Common Performance Anti-Patterns\\n\\n### 1. Excessive Middleware Chains\\n\\n**Problem:**\\n```typescript\\napp.use(logger())\\napp.use(timing())\\napp.use(cors())\\napp.use(csrf())\\napp.use(jwt())\\napp.use(compression())\\n// Every request pays overhead of ALL middleware\\n```\\n\\n**Solution:**\\n```typescript\\n// Apply middleware only where needed\\napp.get('/api/*', jwt(), (c) => {\\n  // JWT only on API routes\\n})\\n\\napp.post('/form', csrf(), (c) => {\\n  // CSRF only on form submissions\\n})\\n```\\n\\n### 2. Synchronous Blocking Operations\\n\\n**Problem:**\\n```typescript\\napp.get('/data', (c) => {\\n  const data = fs.readFileSync('./large-file.json')  // Blocks event loop\\n  return c.json(JSON.parse(data))\\n})\\n```\\n\\n**Solution:**\\n```typescript\\napp.get('/data', async (c) => {\\n  const data = await Bun.file('./large-file.json').json()  // Non-blocking\\n  return c.json(data)\\n})\\n```\\n\\n### 3. Unnecessary JSON Parsing/Stringification\\n\\n**Problem:**\\n```typescript\\napp.post('/proxy', async (c) => {\\n  const body = await c.req.json()          // Parse\\n  const response = await fetch(url, {\\n    body: JSON.stringify(body)             // Re-stringify\\n  })\\n  return c.json(JSON.parse(await response.text()))  // Parse again!\\n})\\n```\\n\\n**Solution:**\\n```typescript\\napp.post('/proxy', async (c) => {\\n  const body = await c.req.text()          // Keep as string\\n  const response = await fetch(url, {\\n    body: body                              // Pass through\\n  })\\n  return new Response(response.body)       // Stream through\\n})\\n```\\n\\n### 4. Creating Functions in Hot Paths\\n\\n**Problem:**\\n```typescript\\napp.get('/users/:id', (c) => {\\n  const userId = c.req.param('id')\\n  \\n  // New function created on every request!\\n  const fetchUser = () => {\\n    return db.query('SELECT * FROM users WHERE id = ?', userId)\\n  }\\n  \\n  return c.json(fetchUser())\\n})\\n```\\n\\n**Solution:**\\n```typescript\\n// Define once, reuse\\nconst fetchUser = (userId: string) => {\\n  return db.query('SELECT * FROM users WHERE id = ?', userId)\\n}\\n\\napp.get('/users/:id', (c) => {\\n  const userId = c.req.param('id')\\n  return c.json(fetchUser(userId))\\n})\\n```\\n\\n### 5. Large Object Creation\\n\\n**Problem:**\\n```typescript\\napp.get('/status', (c) => {\\n  // Creates large object on every request\\n  return c.json({\\n    server: 'my-server',\\n    version: '1.0.0',\\n    capabilities: ['feature1', 'feature2', /* ... */],\\n    metadata: { /* large object */ }\\n  })\\n})\\n```\\n\\n**Solution:**\\n```typescript\\n// Create once, reuse\\nconst STATUS_RESPONSE = {\\n  server: 'my-server',\\n  version: '1.0.0',\\n  capabilities: ['feature1', 'feature2'],\\n  metadata: { /* ... */ }\\n}\\n\\napp.get('/status', (c) => {\\n  return c.json(STATUS_RESPONSE)\\n})\\n```\\n\\n## Runtime-Specific Optimizations\\n\\n### Cloudflare Workers\\n\\n**Environment characteristics:**\\n- V8 isolate per request\\n- Very fast cold starts (sub-millisecond)\\n- 128MB memory limit (common)\\n- Global state not shared between requests\\n\\n**Optimization strategies:**\\n\\n```typescript\\n// Good: Use Workers-specific APIs\\nimport { Hono } from 'hono'\\n\\nconst app = new Hono()\\n\\nexport default {\\n  fetch: app.fetch  // Workers entry point\\n}\\n\\n// Use Workers KV for caching\\napp.get('/cached', async (c) => {\\n  const cached = await c.env.MY_KV.get('key')\\n  if (cached) return c.json(JSON.parse(cached))\\n  \\n  const fresh = await fetchData()\\n  await c.env.MY_KV.put('key', JSON.stringify(fresh))\\n  return c.json(fresh)\\n})\\n```\\n\\n**Avoid:**\\n- Large bundles (impacts startup time)\\n- In-memory caching (each request is isolated)\\n- Heavy computation (use Durable Objects or external services)\\n\\n**Key optimizations:**\\n- Keep bundle size minimal (see bundle-size-optimization.md)\\n- Use Workers KV/R2 for storage\\n- Leverage edge caching (Cache API)\\n- Minimize imports (lazy load when possible)\\n\\n### Deno\\n\\n**Environment characteristics:**\\n- Modern runtime, Web Standards focus\\n- TypeScript native\\n- Secure by default (permissions)\\n- V8 engine\\n\\n**Optimization strategies:**\\n\\n```typescript\\n// Good: Use Deno-native APIs\\nimport { Hono } from 'https://deno.land/x/hono/mod.ts'\\n\\nconst app = new Hono()\\n\\n// Use Deno.serve (faster than HTTP server)\\nDeno.serve(app.fetch)\\n\\n// Use Deno's fast File API\\napp.get('/file', async (c) => {\\n  const file = await Deno.readTextFile('./data.json')\\n  return c.json(JSON.parse(file))\\n})\\n```\\n\\n**Avoid:**\\n- Node.js compatibility layers (slower)\\n- Unnecessary permissions (security overhead)\\n- npm: packages (prefer deno.land)\\n\\n**Key optimizations:**\\n- Use Deno.serve() not polyfilled HTTP servers\\n- Leverage Deno's TypeScript caching\\n- Use Web Standards APIs (faster than compat layers)\\n- Enable unstable APIs for performance features\\n\\n### Bun\\n\\n**Environment characteristics:**\\n- JavaScriptCore (not V8)\\n- Extremely fast startup\\n- Fast file I/O and networking\\n- Node.js compatibility\\n\\n**Optimization strategies:**\\n\\n```typescript\\n// Good: Use Bun-optimized APIs\\nimport { Hono } from 'hono'\\n\\nconst app = new Hono()\\n\\n// Bun.serve is highly optimized\\nexport default {\\n  port: 3000,\\n  fetch: app.fetch\\n}\\n\\n// Use Bun.file (much faster than fs)\\napp.get('/file', async (c) => {\\n  const file = Bun.file('./data.json')\\n  return c.json(await file.json())\\n})\\n```\\n\\n**Avoid:**\\n- Traditional Node.js fs operations\\n- Stream APIs where Bun.file suffices\\n- Polyfills for built-in functionality\\n\\n**Key optimizations:**\\n- Use Bun.serve() native server\\n- Leverage Bun.file for file operations\\n- Use Bun's fast crypto primitives\\n- Take advantage of fast require/import\\n\\n### Node.js\\n\\n**Environment characteristics:**\\n- V8 engine\\n- Mature ecosystem\\n- Wide version support (18.18+)\\n- Libuv for I/O\\n\\n**Optimization strategies:**\\n\\n```typescript\\n// Good: Standard Node.js patterns\\nimport { Hono } from 'hono'\\nimport { serve } from '@hono/node-server'\\n\\nconst app = new Hono()\\n\\nserve({\\n  fetch: app.fetch,\\n  port: 3000\\n})\\n\\n// Use Node.js streams for large responses\\napp.get('/large', (c) => {\\n  const stream = fs.createReadStream('./large-file.txt')\\n  return c.body(stream)\\n})\\n```\\n\\n**Avoid:**\\n- Blocking operations in event loop\\n- Excessive middleware (Node has more overhead than edge runtimes)\\n- Memory leaks (long-running processes)\\n\\n**Key optimizations:**\\n- Use clustering for multi-core utilization\\n- Leverage Node's stream APIs\\n- Profile with --inspect for bottlenecks\\n- Use Node 20+ for performance improvements\\n\\n### AWS Lambda / Serverless\\n\\n**Environment characteristics:**\\n- Cold start penalty (first request)\\n- Warm instances reused\\n- Memory/CPU linked\\n- Time-limited execution\\n\\n**Optimization strategies:**\\n\\n```typescript\\n// Good: Minimize cold start impact\\nimport { Hono } from 'hono'\\nimport { handle } from 'hono/aws-lambda'\\n\\n// Initialize outside handler (runs once per cold start)\\nconst app = new Hono()\\nconst dbConnection = initDB()  // Reused across warm invocations\\n\\napp.get('/api/users', async (c) => {\\n  // Use warm connection\\n  const users = await dbConnection.query('SELECT * FROM users')\\n  return c.json(users)\\n})\\n\\nexport const handler = handle(app)\\n```\\n\\n**Avoid:**\\n- Initializing in handler (runs every request)\\n- Large dependencies (slow cold starts)\\n- Keeping connections open indefinitely\\n\\n**Key optimizations:**\\n- Initialize once, outside handler\\n- Keep bundle size minimal\\n- Use Lambda layers for large dependencies\\n- Choose appropriate memory allocation (affects CPU)\\n- Keep functions warm with scheduled invocations\\n\\n## Multi-Runtime Compatibility Patterns\\n\\n### 1. Conditional Runtime Code\\n\\nWhen runtime-specific optimization is needed:\\n\\n```typescript\\n// Detect runtime\\nconst isBun = typeof Bun !== 'undefined'\\nconst isDeno = typeof Deno !== 'undefined'\\nconst isCloudflare = typeof caches !== 'undefined' && typeof caches.default !== 'undefined'\\n\\n// Use fastest implementation for each runtime\\nconst readFile = isBun\\n  ? (path: string) => Bun.file(path).text()\\n  : isDeno\\n  ? (path: string) => Deno.readTextFile(path)\\n  : (path: string) => fs.promises.readFile(path, 'utf-8')\\n```\\n\\n### 2. Web Standards First\\n\\nPrefer Web Standards APIs (work everywhere):\\n\\n```typescript\\n// Good: Web Standards\\nconst data = await fetch(url)\\nconst json = await data.json()\\n\\n// Avoid: Runtime-specific unless necessary\\nconst data = await Bun.fetch(url)  // Bun-only optimization\\n```\\n\\n### 3. Graceful Degradation\\n\\nProvide fallbacks:\\n\\n```typescript\\n// Optimized path with fallback\\nconst compress = typeof CompressionStream !== 'undefined'\\n  ? (data: string) => {\\n      const stream = new ReadableStream({\\n        start(controller) {\\n          controller.enqueue(new TextEncoder().encode(data))\\n          controller.close()\\n        }\\n      }).pipeThrough(new CompressionStream('gzip'))\\n      return stream\\n    }\\n  : (data: string) => {\\n      // Fallback: return uncompressed\\n      return new ReadableStream({\\n        start(controller) {\\n          controller.enqueue(new TextEncoder().encode(data))\\n          controller.close()\\n        }\\n      })\\n    }\\n```\\n\\n## Performance Testing Across Runtimes\\n\\n### Setup\\n\\nTest your optimization on all supported runtimes:\\n\\n```bash\\n# Node.js\\nnode --version\\nbun run test:node\\n\\n# Bun\\nbun --version\\nbun run test:bun\\n\\n# Deno\\ndeno --version\\nbun run test:deno\\n\\n# Workers (via miniflare or wrangler dev)\\nnpx wrangler dev\\n```\\n\\n### Runtime Benchmark Comparison\\n\\n```typescript\\n// benchmark-multi-runtime.ts\\nimport { bench, run } from 'mitata'\\n\\nbench('my optimization', () => {\\n  myOptimizedFunction()\\n})\\n\\nawait run()\\n\\n// Run on each runtime\\n// bun run benchmark-multi-runtime.ts\\n// deno run benchmark-multi-runtime.ts\\n// node benchmark-multi-runtime.ts\\n```\\n\\nReport results for all runtimes in PR.\\n\\n## API Design for Performance\\n\\n### 1. Lazy Initialization\\n\\n```typescript\\nclass Hono {\\n  private _router?: Router\\n  \\n  get router() {\\n    if (!this._router) {\\n      this._router = new RegExpRouter()\\n    }\\n    return this._router\\n  }\\n}\\n```\\n\\n### 2. Method Chaining (Avoid Overhead)\\n\\n```typescript\\n// Efficient chaining\\napp\\n  .get('/api/users', usersHandler)\\n  .post('/api/users', createUserHandler)\\n  .delete('/api/users/:id', deleteUserHandler)\\n\\n// Each method returns `this`, no extra allocations\\n```\\n\\n### 3. Optional Features\\n\\n```typescript\\n// Make expensive features opt-in\\napp.use(logger())  // Opt-in logging\\napp.use(timing())  // Opt-in timing\\n\\n// Don't:\\n// Built-in logging that can't be disabled\\n```\\n\\n## Performance Debugging Techniques\\n\\n### 1. Profiling\\n\\n```bash\\n# Node.js CPU profiling\\nnode --prof app.js\\nnode --prof-process isolate-*.log > processed.txt\\n\\n# Bun profiling\\nbun --inspect app.ts\\n\\n# Deno profiling\\ndeno run --inspect app.ts\\n```\\n\\n### 2. Memory Profiling\\n\\n```bash\\n# Node.js heap snapshot\\nnode --inspect app.js\\n# Chrome DevTools -> Memory -> Take Snapshot\\n\\n# Look for:\\n# - Memory leaks (growing heap)\\n# - Unexpected large objects\\n# - Retained closures\\n```\\n\\n### 3. Flame Graphs\\n\\n```bash\\n# Generate flame graph (Linux)\\nnode --perf-basic-prof app.js\\nperf record -F 99 -p $(pgrep node) -g -- sleep 30\\nperf script | stackcollapse-perf.pl | flamegraph.pl > flame.svg\\n```\\n\\n## Checklist for Performance-Focused API Design\\n\\n- [ ] Hot paths have minimal overhead\\n- [ ] Optional features are opt-in (tree-shakeable)\\n- [ ] Avoid allocations in request handling\\n- [ ] Prefer Web Standards APIs\\n- [ ] Provide runtime-specific optimizations where beneficial\\n- [ ] Test across all supported runtimes\\n- [ ] Document performance characteristics\\n- [ ] Benchmark before and after\\n\\n## Resources\\n\\n- [V8 optimization tips](https://v8.dev/blog)\\n- [JavaScriptCore performance](https://webkit.org/blog/)\\n- [Cloudflare Workers best practices](https://developers.cloudflare.com/workers/platform/best-practices/)\\n- [Deno performance tips](https://deno.land/manual/runtime/performance)\\n- [Node.js performance](https://nodejs.org/en/docs/guides/simple-profiling/)\\n\\n## Summary\\n\\nPerformance in a multi-runtime framework requires:\\n1. **Minimize overhead** in hot paths (router, middleware, context)\\n2. **Use Web Standards** for portability\\n3. **Optimize for each runtime** where it matters\\n4. **Test everywhere** before claiming performance improvements\\n5. **Document trade-offs** when optimization adds complexity\\n\",\"path\":\"/home/runner/work/gh-aw-trial-hono-copilot-cli/gh-aw-trial-hono-copilot-cli/.github/copilot/instructions/framework-performance-patterns.md\"}",

href=\"https://github.com/honojs/hono/releases\">hono's releases</a>.</em></p>\n<blockquote>\n<h2>v4.9.7</h2>\n<h2>Security</h2>\n<ul>\n<li>Fixed an issue in the <code>bodyLimit</code> middleware where the body size limit could be bypassed when both <code>Content-Length</code> and <code>Transfer-Encoding</code> headers were present. If you are using this middleware, please update immediately.  <a href=\"https://github.com/honojs/hono/security/advisories/GHSA-92vj-g62v-jqhh\">Security Advisory</a></li>\n</ul>\n<h2>What's Changed</h2>\n<ul>\n<li>fix(client): Fix <code>parseResponse</code> not parsing json in react native by <a href=\"https://github.com/lr0pb\"><code>@lr0pb</code></a> in <a href=\"https://redirect.github.com/honojs/hono/pull/4399\">honojs/hono#4399</a></li>\n<li>chore: add <code>.tool-versions</code> file by <a href=\"https://github.com/3w36zj6\"><code>@3w36zj6</code></a> in <a href=\"https://redirect.github.com/honojs/hono/pull/4397\">honojs/hono#4397</a></li>\n<li>chore: update <code>bun install</code> commands to use <code>--frozen-lockfile</code> by <a href=\"https://github.com/3w36zj6\"><code>@3w36zj6</code></a> in <a href=\"https://redirect.github.com/honojs/hono/pull/4398\">honojs/hono#4398</a></li>\n<li>test(jwk): Add tests of JWK token verification by <a href=\"https://github.com/buckett\"><code>@buckett</code></a> in <a href=\"https://redirect.github.com/honojs/hono/pull/4402\">honojs/hono#4402</a></li>\n</ul>\n<h2>New Contributors</h2>\n<ul>\n<li><a href=\"https://github.com/lr0pb\"><code>@lr0pb</code></a> made their first contribution in <a href=\"https://redirect.github.com/honojs/hono/pull/4399\">honojs/hono#4399</a></li>\n<li><a href=\"https://github.com/buckett\"><code>@buckett</code></a> made their first contribution in <a href=\"https://github.com/honojs/hono/compare/v4.9.6...v4.9.7\">https://github.com/honojs/hono/compare/v4.9.6...v4.9.7</a></p>\n<h2>v4.9.6</h2>\n<h2>Security</h2>\n<p>Fixed a bug in URL path parsing (<code>getPath</code>) that could cause path confusion under malformed requests.</p>\n<p>If you rely on reverse proxies (e.g. Nginx) for ACLs or restrict access to endpoints like <code>/admin</code>, please update immediately.</p>\n<p>See advisory for details: GHSA-9hp6-4448-45g2</p>\n<h2>What's Changed</h2>\n<ul>\n<li>chore: update packages in the router bench by <a # Daily Perf Improver - Phase 2: Build Configuration and Performance Engineering Guides

## Summary

This PR completes the Phase 2 setup for the Daily Perf Improver workflow by adding:

1. **Build Steps Configuration** - Automated environment setup for performance development
2. **Performance Engineering Guides** - Comprehensive documentation for rapid performance iteration

## Changes

### 1. Build Steps Action (`.github/actions/daily-perf-improver/build-steps/action.yml`)

Automated setup for performance development environment:
- Sets up Node.js, Bun, and Deno from `.tool-versions`
- Installs dependencies with frozen lockfile
- Builds the project
- Verifies build output
- Logs all steps to `build-steps.log` in repo root

**Usage in workflow:**
```yaml
- uses: ./.github/actions/daily-perf-improver/build-steps
```

### 2. Performance Engineering Guides (`.github/copilot/instructions/`)

Five comprehensive guides to enable rapid performance iteration:

#### `runtime-performance-optimization.md`
- HTTP and router benchmarking workflows
- Hot path optimization techniques (router, middleware, Context)
- Memory optimization strategies
- Runtime-specific tips (Cloudflare Workers, Deno, Bun, Node.js, Lambda)
- Measurement best practices and statistical rigor

#### `build-and-test-performance.md`
- Build time optimization (parallel builds, incremental type checking, caching)
- Test execution speed (parallelization, filtering, coverage optimization)
- CI performance optimization strategies
- Fast iteration loops for performance work
- Development workflow optimization

#### `bundle-size-optimization.md`
- Bundle size monitoring and analysis
- Tree-shaking optimization techniques
- Dependency reduction strategies
- Size budget enforcement
- Analysis tools (esbuild metafile, source-map-explorer)
- Common bundle size pitfalls

#### `performance-measurement-guide.md`
- Existing benchmark infrastructure overview (HTTP, router, JSX)
- Creating new benchmarks (templates, best practices)
- Statistical significance and avoiding false positives
- CI integration for automated performance checks
- Troubleshooting inconsistent results

#### `framework-performance-patterns.md`
- Core performance principles (zero-cost abstractions, pay-for-what-you-use)
- Common performance anti-patterns (excessive middleware, blocking ops, unnecessary parsing)
- Runtime-specific optimizations for all supported platforms
- Multi-runtime compatibility patterns
- Performance debugging techniques (profiling, flame graphs)
- API design checklist for performance

## How These Guides Enable Rapid Iteration

Each guide is structured for quick reference during performance work:

1. **Quick Start sections** - Get measuring immediately
2. **Focused workflows** - Step-by-step optimization processes
3. **Example code** - Copy-paste ready templates
4. **Measurement strategies** - Know what to measure and how
5. **Checklists** - Don't miss critical steps
6. **Troubleshooting** - Common issues and solutions

## Testing

The build-steps action is designed to run in GitHub Actions workflow context and cannot be fully tested in this environment without Bun/Deno installed. However:

- [x] Action syntax validated (YAML structure correct)
- [x] Steps mirror existing CI workflows (`.github/workflows/ci.yml`)
- [x] Uses same setup actions as CI (setup-node@v4, setup-bun@v2, setup-deno@v2)
- [x] Tool versions sourced from `.tool-versions` (consistent with CI)
- [x] Build command matches `package.json` scripts
- [x] Logging appends to `build-steps.log` as specified

## Next Steps

After this PR is merged:

1. **Phase 3** will automatically begin - The Daily Perf Improver will:
   - Use the build-steps action to set up environment
   - Reference these guides for optimization work
   - Select goals from the performance plan (Discussion #2)
   - Implement performance improvements
   - Create PRs with measured impact

2. **Maintainer review requested** for:
   - Accuracy of performance guidance
   - Appropriateness of optimization priorities
   - Any Hono-specific concerns not captured

## Related

- **Planning Discussion**: #2 (Daily Perf Improver - Research and Plan)
- **Workflow**: `.github/workflows/daily-perf-improver.md`
